questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is brought to the ER after sustaining trauma to his spine during a car accident. The bystanders reported that he was not found wearing a seatbelt. Examination reveals weakness in motor movements on the right side with hyperactive reflexes. Suspecting Brown-Sequard syndrome, which of the following clinical findings will be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation

 

Brown Sequard syndrome is produced due to lateral hemisection of spinal cord.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • Ipsilateral weakness +
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense +
  • Contralateral loss of pain & temperature sense one or two levels below lesion +
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of tendon reflex

questions.text:
A 40-year-old truck driver who has been in a long-distance relationship with his wife for the last 5 years, came to the OPD with complaints of weakness jaundice and loss of appetite. His viral markers were done which are given below:

HbSAg +

HbeAg –

HBV DNA +

IgG anti HbCAg +

HIV viral load 65000 copies/mL

CD4 T cell count 320 cells/microliter
 

Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Emtricitabine

 

Emtricitabine is an NRTI that has dual action against both HIV and Hepatitis B. The drugs having activity against both HIV and HBV are:

 

L: Lamivudine

E: Emtricitabine
T: Tenofovir
 

Other options:


Option A) Enfuvirtide is a viral fusion protein inhibitor. It acts against Gp120 and prevents fusion of HIV virus with the CD4 cells

 

Option B) Abacavir is an NRTI. It is known to increase the risk of myocardial infarction. It may lead to severe hypersensitivity reaction particularly in the patients with HLA-B*5701 allele.

 

Option D) Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor. It can lead to hypertriglyceridemia and hypercholesterolemia.

 

Note: Emtricitabine is approved by FDA for its use in HIV but it still has not been FDA approved for Hepatitis B virus infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones. A urine specimen was collected and subjected to microscopic examination. The results revealed several findings, including the one shown below. Additionally, there were signs of red blood cells and white blood cells in the urine. What is the finding that is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cysteine

 

The typical 6-sided crystal is diagnostic of cystinuria in which cystine is excreted not CYSTEINE

 

CYSTINURIA

  • Cystinuria is part of Garrod's tetrad, a group of inborn errors of metabolism.
  • It follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
  • The condition is characterized by a deficiency in the transport of certain amino acids.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Cystinuria is characterized by the abnormal excretion of cystine and, to a lesser extent, lysine, ornithine, and arginine. It is also known as Cystine-lysinuria due to this feature.
  • One of the clinical manifestations of cystinuria is the formation of crystals and calculi in the urine. In acidic pH, cystine crystals can be observed.
  • The condition can lead to obstructive uropathy, which, if left untreated, may progress to renal insufficiency.

Diagnosis:

  • The Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening method for cystinuria. In this test, urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide, and then sodium cyanide is added. If cystine is present, it is reduced to cysteine. The subsequent addition of sodium nitroprusside results in the formation of a magenta-red colored complex.
  • Confirmatory testing for specific aminoaciduria can be done through chromatography.

Treatment:

 

Increasing urinary volume by encouraging fluid intake. Additionally, the solubility of cystine is improved by alkalinizing the urine through the administration of sodium bicarbonate.

questions.text: What is the nerve that passes through the marked foramen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

  • The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which continue as mandibular canal & opens in mental region as mental foramen.
  • Inferior alveolar nerve passes through mandibular foramen.
  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.
  • The IAN continues its path through the mandibular canal and branches off to provide sensation to the lower teeth, gums, and lower lip.

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

questions.text: Below is a partogram depicting a woman in labor, and oxytocin infusion has been given. Please indicate the optimal management for the patient.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cesarean section

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis.

 

It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

choices.text: Dementia with Lewy bodies

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought in by his wife for increasingly bizarre behavior over the last year. She reports that her husband does not recognize her as his wife, but instead believes that she is an impostor who looks exactly like her. He also has the same reaction towards their pet dog, accusing it of being replaced with an identical-looking dog. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Neurologic examination reveals normal motor and sensory function. Which type of dementia is most likely associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dementia with Lewy bodies.

The patient is experiencing Capgras syndrome, a delusional misidentification syndrome where a person believes someone they know has been replaced by an identical-looking impostor. This syndrome is often seen in patients with neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Dementia with Lewy bodies.

a) Alzheimer's disease: The most common form of dementia, typically presents with memory loss, difficulty with language and problem-solving, and changes in mood and personality. Capgras syndrome is not as frequently associated with Alzheimer's disease as it is with DLB.

c) Vascular dementia: The second most common type of dementia, typically presents with step-wise decline in cognitive function, but is not particularly associated with Capgras syndrome.

d) Frontotemporal dementia: A group of conditions characterized by the progressive atrophy of the frontal or temporal lobes of the brain. Patients often have changes in personality and behavior, but Capgras syndrome is not a typical feature.

Therefore, based on the patient's symptoms, Dementia with Lewy bodies is the most likely diagnosis. It is often associated with visual hallucinations and Parkinsonism symptoms, which may not have developed yet in this patient. It's important to note that Capgras syndrome can also be seen in other conditions such as schizophrenia.

choices.text: Desaturate the enzyme
Causes the enzyme to work faster only
Binds to the catalytic site
Participates in feedback regulation

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with hypertension has been prescribed an allosteric modifier as part of their treatment plan. The medication is intended to regulate the activity of an enzyme involved in blood pressure regulation. Which of the following statements is true regarding the allosteric modifier prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Participates in feedback regulation

 

Allosteric Regulation

  1. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  2. Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  3. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  4. In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier.
  5. The binding of substrate to one subunit of the enzyme can positively cooperate with other subunits, enhancing substrate binding. This effect is referred to as positive cooperativity. On the other hand, if the binding of substrate to one subunit reduces the affinity of other sites for substrate binding, it is called negative cooperativity.
  6. In feedback mechanisms, one of the intermediates or products may bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in a series of reactions, leading to either enzyme inhibition or activation.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute chest pain for which he was given sublingual Nitroglycerin. His pain was relieved in 5 minutes. What is the likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Release of Nitric oxide

 

In acute chest pain, nitroglycerin is given sublingually to prevent its first-pass metabolism. The drug acts via increasing the release of nitric oxide.

 

Nitroglycerine is a venodilator, that helps in reducing the preload. It is metabolized into NO which stimulates Guanylate Cyclase and Increases cGMP levels. This leads to endothelium independent coronary vasodilatation. It is given sublingually as it has a high first pass metabolism.

 

The side effects include Monday Morning Headache, reflex Tachycardia, methemoglobinemia.

 

Contraindications include Concurrent use with PDE-5 inhibitors (Sildenafil), Right ventricular infarction and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Calcium channel blockers are the drugs which block L-type voltage gated calcium channels and include Verapamil, Diltiazem, Dihydropyridines (Nifedipine, Nicardipine etc.). Verapamil and Diltiazem have strong myocardial depressant activity. Dihydropyridines mainly dilate arteries. Their side effects include Hypotension, reflex tachycardia, gum hypertrophy etc.

 

Option C) Endothelins are potent vasoconstrictor agents. For acute chest pain, these analogues should not be given as they may aggravate ischemia by reducing blood flow to the heart.

 

Option D) Beta Blockade is the mechanism of action seen with beta receptor antagonists.

choices.text: Hydrocephalus of fetus

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrives at the outpatient department during her 36th week of gestation, reporting breathlessness and significant abdominal distension. During the examination, fetal movements are found to be normal, but fetal parts are not easily palpable, and a muffled fetal heartbeat is detected. The measurement of the symphysis fundal height indicates it to be 41 cm. Upon abdominal examination, the abdomen is found to be tense but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks’ pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

 

About other options:

 

Option A - Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B - Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D - Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer experienced a sudden loss of consciousness while working in the field, after which he was brought to the emergency room. During examination, the patient displayed a body temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit and reduced skin turgor. Among the listed options, which of the following would not be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

In the given question, patient has signs of dehydration and a body temperature of 105°F which is highly suggestive of HEATSTROKE. Sweating is not seen in Heatstroke.

 

Difference between Fever and Heatstroke is as follows:

 

 

 

About other options

  • Option A: Tachypnea - Rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing) can be seen in heatstroke
  • Option B: Hypotension - Dehydration and vasodilation in an attempt to dissipate heat can result in hypotension in heatstroke.
  • Option D: Red hot skin - Heatstroke patients can present with hot, flushed skin due to increased blood flow to the skin surface and the body's inability to dissipate heat effectively.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman at 25 weeks’ gestation with twins presented with urticarial plaques & blisters over her abdomen & inner thighs. She had been feeling increasingly itchy for 2-3 weeks prior to her presentation and then developed blisters for which she had been prescribed clobetasol propionate 0.05% ointment by her GP with no effect. She had a history of itching in the third trimester of her previous pregnancies. On examination, she had several large bullae on her abdomen & each thigh as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigoid gestationis

 

The patient's clinical presentation and history are highly suggestive of Pemphigoid Gestationis (PG), a rare pregnancy-associated blistering disorder that typically begins in the second or third trimester of pregnancy or immediately postpartum. The itching usually begins around the umbilicus and then spreads to the rest of the body. Subsequently, red hives or blisters can appear. This patient's condition did not improve with topical steroids, which might have been effective if the blisters were due to an eczema-like condition.

 

About other options:

 

Option A: Bullous Pemphigoid is also a blistering disease, but it is usually seen in the elderly and is not related to pregnancy.

 

Option C: Pemphigus Vulgaris is a severe autoimmune blistering disorder that typically involves mucous membranes as well as skin, and it is not specifically associated with pregnancy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child, weighing 29 kg, is brought to OPD with a category 3 wound after a dog bite. Currently, equine rabies immunoglobulin is available instead of human rabies immunoglobulin. What dosage should be given as post-exposure prophylaxis for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1160 IU

 

The dose of equine rabies immunoglobulin is 40 IU per kg which comes to 1160 IU

 

The dose of human rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU per kg

 

Remember that anti rabies serum is given once in life time.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with alleged history of consumption of 10 digoxin tablets. On clinical examination, he was found unstable with a heart rate of 50 beats per minute. ECG was done which is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Digibind

 

For the management of Digoxin toxicity having the features of Bradycardia with ECG showing a 3rd degree heart block, we need to administer Digibind, which is an antibody against Digoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Lidocaine is used to treat Ventricular Tachycardia or Ventricular Fibrillation.

 

Option C: DC cardioversion is used for tachyarrhythmias when pharmacologic treatment fails. It is not used in Brady arrhythmias.

 

Option D: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic used for the treatment of GTCS. It can also be used as a class Ib antiarrhythmic drug for the treatment of Digoxin induced Ventricular Tachycardia, or any polymorphic ventricular tachycardia due to QT prolongation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with symptoms of persistent hypertension, severe headaches, and excessive sweating. The doctor in-charge suspects an underlying disorder and decides to perform a urine vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) excretion test of the patient for the same. The test is positive in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pheochromocytoma

 

The half-life of epinephrine is short, ranging from 2 to 5 minutes. In tissues, epinephrine undergoes catabolism through the actions of Catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) and monoamine oxidase (MAO).

 

COMT converts epinephrine to metanephrines, while MAO oxidatively deaminate compounds with the amino group attached to the terminal carbon atom. The major end product of this process is 3-hydroxy-4-methoxy mandelic acid, also known as vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA).

 

Under normal conditions, the excretion of VMA in urine is typically in the range of 2 to 6 mg per 24 hours.

 

However, elevated levels of VMA are observed in conditions such as pheochromocytoma (excessive epinephrine production) and neuroblastoma (excessive nor-epinephrine production).

questions.text: Under what circumstances can hysteroscopy be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asherman syndrome

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

ASHERMAN SYNDROME

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility


Diagnosis:

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

About other options:

 

Option A - Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C - In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D – In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers.
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers.

questions.text: After sleeping with the arm positioned under the head overnight, the individual now encounters a condition of paresis in the morning, characterized by muscle weakness, without any accompanying numbness. What could be the most suitable explanation for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance, and hand and foot enlargement. Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pegvisomant

 

The above clinical features of chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance and hand and foot enlargement are suggestive of Acromegaly.

 

Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that can be used to treat this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue which is used in management of acromegaly, secretory diarrhoea, oesophageal varices etc.

 

Option C) Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist which is used to treat conditions like hyperprolactinemia, prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas (prolactinomas), and is also used off-label to treat Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D) Olcegepant is a CGRP receptor antagonist which is used in management of acute attacks of Migraine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient visits the clinic with a complaint of progressive vision loss. Further evaluation reveals a radiological finding of an aneurysm near the optic chiasma. This aneurysm is believed to be exerting pressure and causing damage. In your diagnosis, which specific artery is the likely culprit behind this aneurysm, leading to the visual impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a history of blurred vision and eye pain in her left eye for the past few months. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes a pigmented lesion on the iris with irregular borders and a raised appearance. The pupil is slightly distorted, and there is mild dilation of the pupil. The intraocular pressure is within normal limits. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A T1 weighted MRI is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C Melanoma

 

T1 hyperintense intra-ocular lesion is noted with associated subretinal effusion. In this age group, the two differentials would be Metastases and Melanoma. Melanin is T1 hyperintense, hence the most likely diagnosis is melanoma.

 

T1 bright structures include:

  • Fat
  • Posterior pituitary
  • Melanin
  • Gd (MR contrast agent)
  • Subacute hemorrhage

Keratin: Cholesteatoma / Epidermoid cyst/ Craniopharyngioma

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you during the early stages of her pregnancy. The ultrasound confirms she is 7 weeks pregnant, and her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. At what point should she begin taking iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 8 to 10 weeks

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy should be started at 14 weeks & continue for 180 days in pregnancy.

 

But given question suggests that patient has Moderate anemia and should be treated immediately. Earliest among the options is 8 to 10 weeks, thus the answer.

 

Severity of Anemia according to Anaemia Mukt Bharat campaign

  • Mild – 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate – 7-9 g%
  • Severe – <7 g %

 

Testing and treating Mild and Moderate Anemia :

  • If mild anemia OR moderate anemia → Give 2 tablets of iron
  • If patient presents late in pregnancy or is unable to tolerate oral iron: Parenteral iron – iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe anemia:

  • Hb < 7 g% → Iron carboxymaltose
  • If patient presents late in the third trimester with severe anemia or Hb is less than 5 g% à ADMIT

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is NOT correctly paired with its target?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. PDL-1 – Rituximab

 

Monoclonal antibodies against PD-L1 includes Atezolizumab, Durvalumab etc. Rituximab is the monoclonal antibody against CD20.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that is a PCSK9 inhibitor. PCSK-9 stands for Pre-protein Convertin Subtilisin Kexin type 9. It binds to the LDL receptor and takes it to the lysosomes where it is broken down. Therefore, PCSK-9 inhibitors act by inhibiting the breakdown of LDL receptors. When more LDL receptors are present, they can take up more LDL cholesterol from blood.

 

Option B) TNF-α – Certolizumab is correctly paired. These drugs act as DMARD by blocking the action of TNF-α and are used in Rheumatoid arthritis, Inflammatory bowel diseases, Psoriatic arthritis etc. TNF-α inhibitors include –

 

ACE In Goli

  • Adalimumab
  • Certolizumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Golimumab

Option D) EGFR – Cetuximab is also correctly paired.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient visits the clinic with complaints of a foul-smelling bloody discharge from the vagina, accompanied by mucous discharge. Upon examination, a necrotizing growth is observed in the cervix, and it appears to have spread to the lateral parametrium. What would be the appropriate course of action for managing this patient's condition?

STAGING OF CA CERVIX

questions.text: A newborn baby has been refusing breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. On the 6th day, the baby develops vomiting and severe jaundice. Urine tested positive with Benedict's reagent, and blood glucose levels were found to be low. What is the most probable cause of these symptoms in the newborn baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The above clinical features are suggestive of classical galactosemia due to Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency.

 

CLASSICAL GALACTOSEMIA:

  • It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

  • Due to a deficiency in a specific enzyme, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, which leads to hypoglycemia.

Other features are:

 

  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
       
  • Treatment:
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyrophosphorylase becomes active.

choices.text: Inhibition of folic acid synthesis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented to the OPD with symptoms of urinary tract infection. She was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. DNA gyrase inhibition

 

Fluroquinolones like Ciprofloxacin, Ofloxacin are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections. They can lead to the side effects like Tendon rupture, arthropathy, photosensitivity, seizures, peripheral neuropathy and even QT prolongation. They are contraindicated in pregnancy and in children under 18 years of age because of they cause damage to the cartilage and tendon. They act by inhibiting the DNA gyrase- thereby inhibiting the replication of the bacteria. They are bactericidal drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Ribosomal inhibition is done by several antimicrobials. It can be categorized as drugs inhibiting 30s subunit which includes Aminoglycosides and Tetracyclines and drugs inhibiting the 50s subunit which includes Macrolides, Linezolid, Streptogramins etc.

 

Option C) Cell Wall synthesis inhibitors are beta lactam drugs, vancomycin, bacitracin, Fosfomycin etc.

 

Option D) Folate synthesis inhibitors include the drugs which inhibits the steps in folate synthesis. The first step involving dihydropteroate synthase is inhibited by Sulfonamides while the other step involving DHFRase is inhibited by Methotrexate, Trimethoprim, Pyrimethamine.

choices.text: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

questions.text: The patient under consideration is a pregnant woman who is at 34 weeks of amenorrhea. Her medical results reveal the following: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Notably, her coagulation profile and renal function tests show normal values. Based on these findings, what would be the appropriate diagnosis for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HELLP syndrome

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension indicates the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for
    • Hemolysis (H)
    • Elevated liver enzymes (EL)
    • Low platelet count (LP).
  • HELLP is an indication for termination of pregnancy. 
  • Ideally steroid cover for fetal lung maturity should be given but that option isn’t there. 
  • MgSO4 also needs to be given for both seizure prophylaxis and neuro-protection of the neonate f/b delivery of the patient.

choices.text: Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: What mechanism is observed in the baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels.

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves → nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) →inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Quinidine

 

Quinidine is a Class Ia anti arrhythmic drug that acts by blocking Na+ channels as well as K+ channels. It can lead to prolonged QT interval and Torsades’ de pointes.

 

Flecainide, Encainide and Propafenone are other drugs that belong to Class Ic antiarrhythmics and can also precipitate Torsades’ de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lignocaine is an ester local anaesthetic which belong to Class Ib anti-arrhythmic agents. It is the drug of choice in controlling digoxin-induced ventricular arrythmias and should not be used in Supra-ventricular arrythmia. Class Ib anti-arrhythmic agents are not known to cause QT prolongation.


Option C) Magnesium sulphate is given in the treatment of Torsades de pointes (QT prolongation).


Drugs causing Torsades de Pointes are :

  • Class 1c and 1a anti-arrhythmic agents, Sotalol, Amiodarone.
  • Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Gatifloxacin, Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin, Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole, Itraconazole
  • Haloperidol, Ziprasidone, Thioridazine
  • Tricyclic anti-depressants
  • Cisapride, Astemizole, Terfenadine

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the Pharmacology department of the AIIMS New Delhi where your SR asks you the name of the drug which acts by causing both decreased bone resorption and increased bone formation. Which of the following will be the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Strontium ranelate

 

Strontium Ranelate is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. It acts by preventing both bone formation and bone resorption.
 

Option B - Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate that acts only by reducing bone resorption.

questions.text: A 30-year-old 70 kg man who presents to the emergency department with symptoms of weakness, dizziness, and confusion. The healthcare team suspects hyponatremia based on his clinical presentation and laboratory results which showed serum Na+ of 120 meq/litre. Calculate the patient's sodium deficit.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

questions.text: What is the typical FiO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen) delivered by a non-rebreathing mask?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 80%

 

A non-rebreathing mask is a high-flow oxygen delivery system used to provide a relatively high concentration of oxygen to patients in respiratory distress or requiring significant oxygen supplementation. The mask has one-way valves and a reservoir bag, which prevents the patient from inhaling exhaled gases and ensures a higher concentration of oxygen with each breath.

 

The typical FiO2 delivered by a non-rebreathing mask is around 80%. This means that the patient is breathing a mixture of approximately 80% oxygen and 20% room air. The mask allows for better control over oxygen delivery than standard nasal cannulas or simple face masks, making it particularly useful in critical care and emergency settings.

questions.text: A 25-year-old businessman has presented to the OPD with the complaints of painful swelling over the great toe of his right foot. His personal history reveals that he is an alcoholic. His serum uric acid levels are found to be raised. He has been prescribed a drug which inhibits the migration of granulocytes. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Colchicine

 

Colchicine is used in acute gout to control the inflammation. It acts by blocking the microtubules and thereby blocking the chemotaxis or migration of leucocytes. It causes severe diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Probenecid increases the excretion of the uric acid, so it is prescribed in chronic gout to the patients who are under-secretors. It is called as uricosuric drugs. Other examples include Benzbromarone, Lesinurad, Sulfinpyrazone.

 

Option C & D) Allopurinol & Febuxostat inhibits the xanthine oxidase enzyme and prevents synthesis of uric acid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is examined, presenting with lens subluxation and cognitive delay. She exhibits physical characteristics suggestive of Marfan syndrome. There is also a family history of similar symptoms among her sisters. She has been diagnosed with classical homocystinuria. Considering her condition, what dietary supplement would be most beneficial in reducing her risk of heart attacks?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pyridoxine

 

a) Pyridoxine: also known as Vitamin B6, is used as a treatment in some individuals with homocystinuria. It acts as a cofactor for the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, promoting the conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine. This reduces the level of homocysteine in the body, potentially decreasing the risk of heart attack.

 

b) Methionine: Methionine is an amino acid that is elevated in individuals with homocystinuria. Supplementing with more methionine would likely exacerbate the condition, increasing homocysteine levels and potentially elevating the risk of heart disease.

 

c) Methylcobalamin: This is a form of Vitamin B12 that can be used to lower homocysteine levels by promoting its re-methylation to methionine. This pathway is usually not the primary problem in classical homocystinuria, so while it might help somewhat, it is not usually the first-line treatment.

 

d) Niacin: Niacin, or Vitamin B3, is not directly involved in the metabolism of homocysteine. While it is used to lower cholesterol and decrease the risk of heart disease, it would not be directly beneficial for the metabolic issues in homocystinuria.

questions.text: The patient in the post-operative ward is a 22-year-old with type 1 diabetes mellitus who underwent a cesarean section due to a failed induction for preeclampsia with severe features. She is currently experiencing drowsiness and altered mental status. Her treatment includes a continuous infusion of magnesium sulfate and intravenous insulin. Upon examination, her pulse rate is 70 beats per minute, blood pressure measures 140/98 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 10 breaths per minute. Lung auscultation reveals normal air entry bilaterally, while abdominal examination shows a firm uterus with normal tenderness, an intact Pfannenstiel scar, and no significant vaginal bleeding. However, both patellar reflexes are absent. Notably, a urine dipstick test for protein and sugar is negative, but her capillary glucose level measures 270 mg%. What can be the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Magnesium sulphate toxicity

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
       
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    •  
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    •  
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
       
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

questions.text: A first-year Orthopedic Postgraduate develops a crush on a female intern who is posted in his ward. Despite his feelings, he finds himself being overly strict with her and reprimands her for minor mistakes while overlooking similar errors made by other interns. Which defense mechanism is he primarily using?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reaction formation


Reaction formation is a defense mechanism in which an individual acts in a manner opposite from his or her beliefs. In this scenario, the resident has feelings of attraction (a crush) towards the intern, but he reacts in the opposite manner by being overly strict and critical of her, despite her mistakes being similar to other interns whom he does not treat the same way.

Let's understand the other options as well:

b. Projection - This is a defense mechanism where a person attributes their own unacceptable thoughts, feelings, or motives to another person. In this scenario, if the resident was projecting, he would be attributing his feelings of attraction to the intern, perhaps believing that she is the one with feelings for him.

c. Denial - Denial is a defense mechanism where a person refuses to accept reality or facts, acting as if a painful event, thought, or feeling did not exist. If the resident was in denial, he would refuse to acknowledge his feelings of attraction for the intern.

d. Displacement - This is a defense mechanism where a person redirects their feelings or responses from an object or person that is threatening or hurtful to a safer, more acceptable one. In this context, if the resident was using displacement, he might have redirected his anger or frustration from a different source, such as a demanding superior or challenging patient, to the intern. But in the provided scenario, the resident's reactions seem specifically related to his feelings for the intern, rather than a general displacement of emotion, making reaction formation a more fitting description of his behavior.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. B is competitive antagonist

 

The DRC of drug B has shifted to the right of the DRC of drug A, although the height of the two curves is the same. On the other hand, Drug C has shifted the curve down.

 

Further height of curve in Drug A and B is same but more than Drug C.

 

Curve of Drug A is on most left followed by Drug C and then Drug B.

 

 

In competitive antagonism, two or more substrates/ligands compete for the same active site on the enzyme or receptor. This leads to decrease in potency of the drug, because the same effect will now be produced at a higher dose, in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

 

In non-competitive antagonism, the inhibitor binds at the allosteric site making conformational changes in the enzyme or receptor. This decrease the maximal response that could be generated by the binding of the ligand/substrate and the receptor/enzyme leading to reduced efficacy.

 

Therefore, the following inferences can be drawn from the given image:

  • The efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C
  • The Potency of Drug A > Drug C > Drug B
  • Drug B is a competitive inhibitor of Drug A
  • Drug C is a non-competitive inhibitor of Drug A

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. The medical team suspects a potential cardiac issue and orders a series of blood tests, including lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) measurement. Upon reviewing the test results, it is found that the LDH ratio is flipped. What does the flipped LDH ratio imply?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. LDH1 > LDH 2

 

Normally LDH 2 is predominant in the blood and LDH 1 is predominant in the heart. During a myocardial infarction, due to damage to the cardiac tissue, LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream resulting in a high LDH1:LDH2 ratio called flipped LDH ratio (LDH1 > LDH2).

 

 

Types of LDH

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient, Mr. Subedar Singh, has a longstanding diagnosis of bipolar disorder and has been on lithium therapy for the past 5 years. He presents with complaints of excessive urination and excessive thirst for the past several weeks. His laboratory studies show normal glucose and serum electrolyte levels, and the urine output is increased without signs of infection or glucose. His lithium levels are within the therapeutic range. The patient's symptoms are most likely a side effect of his medication. Which of the following medications would be the most appropriate next step in the management of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrochlorothiazide

Mr. Singh is most likely experiencing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, a known side effect of long-term lithium therapy. This condition is characterized by a decreased ability of the kidney to concentrate urine, leading to polyuria and subsequent polydipsia.

A) Hydrochlorothiazide - Correct Answer. Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic, paradoxically, it reduces urine output in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. It works by increasing sodium absorption in the proximal tubule and decreasing flow to the diluting segments of the nephron, thereby limiting the dilution of urine and reducing urine volume.

B) Furosemide - Incorrect. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that works by inhibiting the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which would cause an increased urine output. This is not desirable in a patient already experiencing excessive urination.

C) Lisinopril - Incorrect. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor and primarily used for treating hypertension and heart failure. It does not have a role in managing the symptoms of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

D) Metformin - Incorrect. Metformin is an antidiabetic drug that reduces glucose production in the liver and improves the body's sensitivity to insulin, but it does not have an effect on the symptoms related to lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never be written in abbreviation form (e.g., never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc. should not be used in prescription.

Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the paediatrician with the complaint of one eye larger than the other and frequent rubbing of the eyes by the baby. On examination, one of his eyes appears larger than the other with a hazy cornea and raised intraocular pressure. Suspecting Glaucoma, which of the following medications should be avoided in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Brimonidine

 

Brimonidine is an α2 agonist that works in glaucoma by reducing the secretion of Aqueous humor from the ciliary processes. It can cross the blood brain barrier and can cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates. Therefore, it is unsafe in infants and not recommended in children less than 2 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Timolol is a non-selective beta blocker. It reduces formation of the aqueous humor and is safe in infants.

 

Option C) Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue (PGF2-alpha) which reduces uveoscleral outflow. It is the drug of choice in open angle glaucoma and is safe in children.

 

Option D) Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the formation of the aqueous humor.

questions.text: Staphylococcal infection causes all the following skin diseases except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Erysipelas

 

Erysipelas is a group A streptococcal infection of the superficial dermis and consists of well-demarcated, erythematous, edematous, warm plaques.

 

IMPETIGO, ECTHYMA, AND FURUNCULOSIS

  • Option A: Impetigo is a common superficial bacterial infection of skin caused most often by S. aureus and in some cases by group A β-hemolytic streptococci. The primary lesion is a superficial pustule that ruptures and forms a characteristic yellow-brown honey-colored crust.
  • Blisters are caused by the production of exfoliative toxin by S. aureus phage type II. This is the same toxin responsible for staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome, often resulting in dramatic loss of the superficial epidermis due to blistering. The latter syndrome is much more common in children than in adults; however, it should be considered along with toxic epidermal necrolysis and severe drug eruptions in patients with widespread blistering of the skin.
  • Option C: Ecthyma is a deep non-bullous variant of impetigo that causes punched-out ulcerative lesions.
  • Treatment of both ecthyma and impetigo involves gentle debridement of adherent crusts, which is facilitated by the use of soaks and topical antibiotics in conjunction with appropriate oral antibiotics.
  • Option D: Furunculosis is also caused by S. aureus. A furuncle, or boil, is a painful, erythematous nodule that can occur on any cutaneous surface. The lesions may be solitary but are most often multiple. Family members or close contacts may also be affected. Current recommendations for methicillin- sensitive infections are β-lactam antibiotics. Warm compresses and nasal mupirocin are helpful therapeutic additions.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child comes to the physician's office complaining of swelling and pain in the knees. His mother says, the swelling occurred for no reason, and it keeps getting worse." The initial diagnosis is Lyme disease. When talking to the mother and child, questions related to which of the following would be important to include in the initial history?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Headaches, malaise, or sore throat 

 

LYME DISEASE

  • Most common vector borne disease in US
  • Caused by spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi
  • Bite of the infected tic
  • Erythema migrans
  • It's typically a circular red area that sometimes clears in the middle forming a bull's-eye pattern
  • Treatment: Doxycycline

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH
Stop warfarin and start heparin
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.text:
What is the most suitable course of action in managing a pregnant woman who is currently at 36 weeks of gestation, has mitral stenosis, and is undergoing warfarin therapy at a dosage of 4mg per day due to a prosthetic valve replacement?

(LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Stop warfarin and start LMWH

  • Warfarin is teratogenic
  • In doses > 5mg; there is an 8% risk of warfarin embryopathy
  • In pregnancy, warfarin should be changed to LMWH or UFH in the 1st trimester (especially if warfarin is being given > 5 mg/ day).
  • After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery where warfarin is again replaced by LMWH or UFH.
  • Aspirin can be added in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis
  • Heparin is discontinued just before delivery and resumed 6-12 hours after delivery
  • Warfarin can be restarted postnatally as it is not excreted in breast milk.

questions.text: A 27-year-old individual was diagnosed with uterus didelphys. Among the options provided, which one is least likely to be a complication associated with this particular uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Transverse lie

  • Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys.
  • A transverse lie is more likely to be seen with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus.
  • Uterus didelphys usually has a good reproductive outcome. However, it can present with
    • Spontaneous abortion
    • Preterm labor
    • Breech presentation
    • Increased risk of cesarean delivery
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Low birth weight (<2.5kg)
    • Perinatal death
  • A rare variant of uterine didelphys is the OHVIRA syndrome wherein there is Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis. In this endometriosis may be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rivaroxaban

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Other options:

  • Bivalrudin is an injectable Direct Thrombin (Factor IIa) inhibitor.
  • Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor
  • Enoxaparin is a Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH).

questions.text: Identify the prominent nerve pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Great auricular nerve

 

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

 

 

Great auricular nerve:

  • The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.
  • The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.
     

Clinical considerations:

  • ﻿﻿Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • ﻿﻿Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, and decreased exercise tolerance over the past six months. He has noticed a decrease in muscle mass and an increase in abdominal fat deposition. He also reports experiencing frequent headaches and occasional blurred vision. The laboratory test results come back, showing low levels of IGF-I. IGF-I is synthesized by which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liver

 

The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is the liver. IGF-I is produced in response to stimulation by growth hormone (GH), which is primarily secreted by the pituitary gland. However, while GH stimulates IGF-I production, it is the liver that is responsible for producing the majority of circulating IGF-I in the body.

 

Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called "somatomedins"

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Also called as insulin-like growth factor (IGF) as effects are similar to insulin
  • Four types are present - Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as "insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • Binds to carrier protein in blood
  • Half-life - about 20 Hrs
  • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

 

Reference – Textbook of Medical physiology Guyton and Hall, 11th edition, page no. 924

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her first prenatal visit at 11 weeks of gestation. On transvaginal ultrasound, a gestational sac is seen measuring 28mm in diameter, but no yolk sac or fetal pole is identified. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blighted ovum

 

A gestational sac measuring 25mm or more in diameter without a yolk sac or fetal pole is consistent with a blighted ovum, which is a type of early pregnancy loss where a fertilized egg implants in the uterus but fails to develop into an embryo.

 

Ectopic pregnancy would typically present with a gestational sac outside the uterus, and molar pregnancy would show characteristic features on ultrasound such as a snowstorm appearance. Early intrauterine pregnancy should show a yolk sac and/or fetal pole by 11 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with Carcinoma bladder for which he was receiving chemotherapy. 4 hours later he developed intractable vomiting. Which of the following is the most effective anti-emetic that should be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Granisetron

 

Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor blocker. These 5HT3 receptor blockers are the most effective antiemetics for chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Domperidone is a Dopamine agonist and it acts on the dopamine receptors outside the Blood brain barrier and prevent nausea and vomiting. It cannot cross the Blood brain barrier.

 

Option B) Tegaserod acts as a partial agonist at serotonin 5-HT4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract. By stimulating these receptors, tegaserod enhances the release of acetylcholine and other neurotransmitters, leading to increased gut motility and accelerated transit of stool through the intestines. This helps relieve constipation and improve symptoms associated with IBS-C.

 

Option D) Doxylamine is an antihistamine medication which is indicated along with Pyridoxine in management of Morning sickness in early pregnancy.

choices.text: Methotrexate with folinic acid

questions.text: Six months ago, a woman underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy. However, she now returns with ongoing symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. After conducting a thorough evaluation, it was observed that her beta-hCG levels remained persistently elevated, and cannonball foci were detected on the chest X-ray. What would be the most suitable course of action to manage this case effectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate with folinic acid

  • This is a clear case of post molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases
  • Treatment is based on prognostication and staging as shown below

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7: HIGH RISK
  • The above patient appears to be low risk choriocarcinoma
  • Low risk choriocarcinoma is treated with multi dose single agent chemotherapy i.e. Methotrexate
  • This is given as a multi dose regime (Day 1,3,5,7) alternating with inj Folinic acid (Day 2,4,6,8)
  • High risk choriocarcinoma is treated by multiple agent chemotherapy (EMACO)
  • Remember lung metastases is LOW RISK

questions.text: During pregnancy, acute fatty liver most commonly manifests in which trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Third trimester

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (ALP) is a life-threatening medical disorder involving liver.
  • It occurs during late second and third trimester.
  • The diagnosis is made by Swansea Criteria wherein 6 or more of the following are required to make the diagnosis
    • Vomiting
    • Abdominal pain
    • Polydipsia, polyurea
    • Encephalopathy
    • Coagulopathy (raised PTaPTT)
    • increased bilirubin
    • Increased uric acid levels
    • Increased creatinine
    • Leukocytosis
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Raised liver enzymes.
    • Raised serum ammonia levels.
    • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
    • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy
  • Risk factors include: Maternal obesity, male fetus, primigravida and multiple pregnancy

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the breast clinic with a painless lump in her left breast that she discovered during a self-examination. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, firm, and non-tender mass of 2 cm is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The overlying skin is smooth, and there is no nipple discharge or lymphadenopathy. Mammogram is shown below. Classify the following mammography lesion as per BIRADS staging:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. BIRADS 2

 

This is a well-defined round mass accompanied with coarse popcorn calcifications, typical of an involuting fibroadenoma. As a result, it is categorized as a benign lesion (BIRADS 2).

 

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 682

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows height for age to be less than expected. The parents also have a history of Incorrect feeding method. What is the appropriate term for the above-mentioned condition?

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented to OPD with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What can be the diagnosis?

FIGO Classification of Fibroids

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 6-mercaptopurine

 

6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analogue that acts by inhibiting the purine synthesis, required for the synthesis of DNA, in the S phase of the cell cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B - Mitomycin acts as an alkylating agent which leads to DNA damage by creating cross links. It is used in management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C - Actinomycin acts by creating single-strand breaks in DNA. It blocks RNA transcription as well.

 

Option D - L-Asparaginase causes the breakdown of asparagine and thus interferes with protein synthesis. It is used in treatment of ALL.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

choices.text: It should not be prescribed with Erythromycin
Patients on theophylline develop arrythmias due to its Adenosine antagonism
It is a non-specific Phosphodiesterase inhibitor
Patients may develop diuresis due to its phosphodiesterase inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Theophylline is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Patients may develop diuresis due to its phosphodiesterase inhibition.

 

The adenosine (A1) receptor blockage is what causes theophylline's diuretic action.

 

Theophylline is a non-specific phosphodiesterase inhibitor which is used in patients with Status Asthmaticus.

 

Whereas PDE4 inhibition prevents the release of cytokines and chemokines, which reduces immune cell migration and activation, PDE3 inhibition relaxes bronchial smooth muscle. Blocking adenosine receptors prevents bronchoconstriction.

 

By inhibiting A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT, diuresis is brought on.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that is an enzyme inhibitor, which inhibits the cytochrome enzymes, thereby inhibiting the metabolism of theophylline. This can lead to rise of theophylline to toxic levels in the body.

 

Option B) Due to adenosine antagonism, patients on theophylline may develop diuresis, arrythmias and seizures

 

Option C) It is a non-specific phosphodiesterase inhibitor.

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 126 mg/dL

 

A patient is said to have overt diabetes if:

  • Fasting blood sugar ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%

Fetal congenital malformations are high if there is maternal hyperglycemia during the first trimester (period of organogenesis) i.e., if she has pre-gestational diabetes (Not Gestational Diabetes)

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with persistent gastroesophageal reflux symptoms despite medication. Upon further investigation, it's noted that the patient has a history of hiatal hernia. During an imaging study, it's revealed that certain structures are passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. However, one structure does not pass through this opening. Which of the mentioned structures is an exception and does not traverse through the aortic opening of the diaphragm in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log (dose) and the response of three drugs, A, B, and C. Which of these drugs has the highest potency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The potency of a drug corresponds to the power of the drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.

 

The more left the curve is on the DRC, the greater is its potency.

 

On the other hand, efficacy means the maximum response that is produced by a drug. In a DRC, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug is.

 

Therefore, in this case,

  • The potency of Drug A > Drug B > Drug C
  • The Efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy, of African descent, presented with a large boggy mass on his scalp with overlying crusting as shown in the image below. Skin scrapings and hair pluckings were taken for mycology. Microsporum canis was grown on culture. What is the most suitable treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral griseofulvin

 

Systemic treatment is needed for tinea capitis and for kerion, however topical treatment in addition may decrease transmission. Terbinafine is DOC for the treatment of tinea capitis caused by trichophyton species, however, terbinafine was found to be less effective than griseofulvin for microsporum infections. So the best option for this patient having microsporum as the causative agent for tinea capitis would be oral griseofulvin.

questions.text: A 18-year-old male patient visits the dermatology clinic with complaints of itchy lesions on his skin. Upon examination, the patient's tongue is noted to be red and beefy with the findings on skin as shown below. Which of the following additional medical histories would you like to inquire about or elicit from this alcoholic patient to aid in diagnosing the cause of his skin lesions and tongue condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ask for diarrhea and history of memory loss

 

The clinical scenario along with Casal’s necklace suggests a diagnosis to pellagra.

 

The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). It is seen in patients with pellagra, as a result of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency or tryptophan deficiency.

 

Deficiency of niacin leads to the clinical condition called pellagra. Pellagra is an Italian word, meaning “rough skin”. Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of Tryptophan as well as Niacin. Pellagra is seen more in women; this may be because tryptophan metabolism is inhibited by estrogen metabolites.

 

The symptoms of pellagra are (3 Ds):

  1. Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs, especially in the feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace. The dermatitis is precipitated by exposure to sunlight
  2. Diarrhea: The diarrhea may be mild or severe with blood and mucus. This may lead to weight loss. Nausea and vomiting may also be present.
  3. Dementia: It is frequently seen in chronic cases.

Delirium is common in acute pellagra. Irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory are more common in mild cases. Ataxia, and spasticity are also seen.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with vulval warts. What is the ideal treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cryotherapy

 

“Cryotherapy is a safe treatment of vulva warts in pregnancy.”

 

Pregnancy and genital warts:

  •  Imiquimod, sine catechins, podophyllin, and podofilox should not be used during pregnancy as they are teratogenic.
  •  Genital warts can proliferate and become friable during pregnancy.
  •  Rarely, HPV types 6 and 11 can cause respiratory papillomatosis in infants and children, although the route of transmission (i.e., transplacental, perinatal, or postnatal) is not completely understood.
  • Pregnant women with genital warts should be counselled concerning the low risk for warts on the larynx (recurrent respiratory papillomatosis) in their infants or children.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with ADPKD was prescribed tolvaptan. After a few weeks, he presented with dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increased free water clearance

 

Tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, that blocks the action of ADH in the kidney. The V2 receptor is a GPCR that acts by increasing the levels of intracellular cAMP, leading to fusion of the Aquaporin 2 containing vesicles with the luminal plasma membrane, which helps in reabsorption of solute free water from the tubules. Tolvaptan therefore increases the free water clearance by decreasing all these effects.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is suspected to have a baby with down syndrome. In which trimester, quadruple test is done for antenatal screening of Down’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 2nd

 

First trimester investigation: Beta HCG & PAPPA (pregnancy associated plasma protein A)

 

Second trimester investigations: triple scan (Beta HCG, alpha feto protein and estriol) & quadruple scan which has Inhibin A

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of easy fatigability, irritability, and an inability to concentrate. Concerned about the symptoms, the pediatrician orders several laboratory tests, including a bone marrow aspiration. The bone marrow aspiration reveals specific findings as shown in figure A and B (under oil immersion). Based on these findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely to be responsible for the boy's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glucocerebrosidase

 

The given clinical scenario of a child with easy fatiguability, irritability, and inability to concentrate is suggestive of Gaucher's disease. The deficient enzyme is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase), show Gaucher's cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance.

 

Gaucher cells are normal scavenger cells called macrophages that become full of unprocessed glucocerebroside. Gaucher cells accumulate primarily in the spleen, liver and bone marrow, causing organ inflammation and dysfunction.

 

 

Option D: Deficiency of N-acetylglucosaminidase leads to type III mucopolysaccharidoses called Sanfillipo's disease wherein there is accumulation of heparan sulfate leading to severe cognitive degeneration.

questions.text: Which of the following sites is commonly used for intraoperative core body temperature monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pulmonary artery

 

Intraoperative core body temperature monitoring is essential to ensure patient safety and prevent perioperative complications related to hypothermia. While various non-invasive methods like forehead, wrist, or axilla temperature measurements are commonly used, the most accurate and reliable method is the direct measurement of core body temperature via the pulmonary artery. This method involves inserting a specialized temperature probe into the pulmonary artery, which allows continuous and precise monitoring of the patient's core temperature during surgery and critical care settings. It is especially valuable in maintaining normothermia and guiding appropriate interventions to prevent hypothermia-related complications.

choices.text: Collett and Edwards classification
West haven classification

questions.text: A newborn is suspected to have truncus arteriosus. According to which classification, truncus arteriosus is divided into four types?
questions.solution: Ans: A. Collett and Edwards classification

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presented to the endocrinology clinic with concerns about uncontrolled blood sugar levels. The patient reports that despite taking his prescribed insulin, he was experiencing episodes of hyperglycemia and increased hunger. Upon further evaluation, it is found that the patient's insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased. In response to this change in the ratio, which enzyme is activated as part of the body's physiological response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glucose-6-phosphatase

  1. Glucagon is the most potent hyperglycemic hormone. It is anti-insulin in nature. Therefore, the net effect is decided by insulin glucagon ratio. Decrease in the ratio indicates higher levels of glucagon.
  2. Glucagon is mainly glycogenolytic. The active form of glycogen phosphorylase is formed under the influence of glucagon. Liver is the primary target for the glycogenolytic effect of glucagon.
  3. It depresses glycogen synthesis.
  4. Gluconeogenesis is favored by glucagon by inducing enzymes like PEPCK, glucose-6-phosphatase and fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase.
  5. Glucagon increases plasma free fatty acid level. In adipose tissue glucagon favors beta oxidation as it activates carnitine acyl transferase. The mitochondrial acetyl CoA levels increase.
  6. Ketogenesis is favored.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Ischemic heart disease is posted for Coronary artery bypass graft surgery. You want beat to beat blood pressure measurement intraoperatively to guide you through the hemodynamic changes. Which among the following is the ideal artery for invasive blood pressure measurement ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Radial

 

Radial artery, because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications, is the preferred for invasive blood pressure monitoring.

 

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are

  • Ulnar
  • Brachial
  • Axillary
  • Femoral arteries
  • Less commonly dorsalis pedis
  • Posterior tibial
  • Superficial temporal arteries.

 

Reference : Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition, page 155

questions.text: A 14 weeks old baby was brought to OPD for a routine vaccination. In evening, the baby had a seizure episode. Which vaccine could have been responsible for this event?
