questions.text: A 12 years-old child presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows a grey membrane on the right tonsil extending to the anterior pillar. Which of the following medium will be ideal for the culture of the throat swab for a rapid identification of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Loeffler's serum slope

  • The clinical diagnosis of diphtheria is based on the constellation of sore throat; adherent tonsillar, pharyngeal, or nasal pseudomembranous lesions; and low-grade fever.
  • The diagnosis requires the isolation of Corynebacterium diphtheriaefrom the lesion.
  • Isolation by culture is done using enrichment media:
  • Loeffler's serum slope: rapid growth (6-8 hours)
  • Tellurite blood agar: delayed growth (up to 2 days).
  • Tellurite inhibits the growth of most other bacteria, acting as a selective agent.
     

Important points:

  • C. diphtheriae is a non-encapsulated, non-motile, gram-positive bacillus.
  • Pathogenic strains can result in severe localized upper respiratory infection, localized cutaneous infections, and rarely systemic infection.

choices.text: Otosclerosis, Acoustic neuroma, Noise induced hearing loss, Meniere’s disease
Noise induced hearing loss, Meniere’s disease, Otosclerosis, Acoustic neuroma
Noise induced hearing loss, Meniere’s disease, Acoustic neuroma, Otosclerosis
Otosclerosis, Meniere’s disease, Acoustic neuroma, Noise induced hearing loss

questions.text: Following are the various investigations pertaining to various ear disorders. Identify them in sequence.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Noise induced hearing loss, Meniere’s disease, Acoustic neuroma, Otosclerosis

  1. Audiogram shows dip at 4000Hz which is seen in noise-induced hearing loss
  2. It shows abnormal electrocochleography which is seen in meniere disease
  3. MRI shows ice cream cone appearance at cerebellopontine angle which indicates acoustic neuroma. Also, contrast enhancement can be observed,
  4. Flamingo-pink blush seen through the normal tympanic membrane at the area corresponding to stapes footplate. This is schwartz sign, seen in otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back followed by swollen, red & erythematous joints. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal & genitourinary infections & manifests as asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.
  • It is frequently associated with enthesitis.
  • Extra-articular manifestations are common & include urethritis, conjunctivitis, uveitis, & mucocutaneous lesions.
  • It occurs most commonly in young men & is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.
  • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or Ureaplasma urealyticum).
  • The arthritis frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly knee & ankle).
  • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.
  • The mucocutaneous lesions may include balanitis, stomatitis, & keratoderma blennorrhagicum, indistinguishable from pustular psoriasis.
  • Anterior uveitis, which can develop at any time in HLA-B27-positive patients, is a more clinically significant ocular complication.

questions.text: In reference to the provided box-whisker plot, which statement is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Mean > Median > Mode

 

The given box-whisker plot represents a positively (or right) skewed distribution. In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.

 

To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

questions.text: A 20-years-old male patient was admitted to the ICU. He was diagnosed with COVID-19 disease and had symptoms of respiratory distress, high grade fever, cough and weakness. On examination, his Respiratory rate was 28 breaths per minute. On auscultation, crackles were heard over the bilateral lower lung fields. His X-ray chest was ordered which is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this disease is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A PEEP of 3-5 cm of H2O is recommended for the recruitment of the alveoli

 

The given clinical scenario (COVID with severe respiratory distress) and X-ray showing bat wing edema are suggestive of ARDS or acute respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Patients, with acute respiratory distress syndrome, are prone to develop pneumothorax. Due to reduced compliance, there is increased risk of barotrauma. So, a high-volume ventilation is not recommended.

 

In treatment of ARDS:

  • Low volume ventilation of 6 ml/Kg is recommended (Normal tidal volume is 12 mL/kg)
  • Plateau pressure = < 30 cm/H2O
  • Respiratory rate = < 35/min
  • Prone position ventilation
  • ECMO is needed in patient with weakened heart and lung
  • Limited fluids and diuretics to maintain normal LA pressure
  • Ensure neuromuscular paralysis
  • Steroids, Surfactant therapy and high frequency jet ventilation have no role in management of ARDS.

questions.text: Which layer is responsible for preserving the cornea's hydration and transparency among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelial cells

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea dehydrated, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

The different layers of cornea:

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells

questions.text: A 30-year-old ingests a large amount of acetaminophen and 12 hours later develops malaise and abdominal pain. Laboratory studies show an elevated ALT. N-acetylcysteine is administered to aid in generation of which of the following molecules within cells as a protective mechanism to reduce the number of free radicals?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Reduced glutathione

 

The glutathione peroxidase system is designed to help break down free radicals generated from various forms of cell injury. This system works constantly in the background with small numbers of free radicals. Disease processes generating greater amounts of free radicals and cell injury can overwhelm this system, as with acetaminophen toxicity to hepatocytes in this case.

 

N-acetylcysteine is administered to aid in generation of reduced glutathione which can help in countering the damage caused by free radicals. 

 

Catalases decompose hydrogen peroxide, but they are not specifically designed to scavenge free radicals. Hydrogen peroxide is generated by some cells, such as neutrophils, in order to destroy phagocytized microbes. Hydrogen peroxide is generated by some cells, such as neutrophils, in order to destroy phagocytized microbes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

 

To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.

 

Hypoparathyroidism is a common complication of thyroid surgery, and its effects are usually temporary, lasting for a period of 4-6 weeks.

 

This condition can be diagnosed when there are decreased serum calcium and/or PTH levels or symptomatic hypocalcemia.

 

Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty focusing on distant objects. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist diagnoses the patient with simple myopic astigmatism. Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: the power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere), the power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder), and the axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

TYPES OF ASTIGMATISM:

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained open fracture of femur which was operated & stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rail fixator

 

Open Fractures

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries & are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues & contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia are the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:
    • Type I injuries: low energy & wounds are < 1 cm.
    • Type II injuries: wound length of 2-10 cm with moderate soft tissue damage & wound contamination.
    • Type III injuries: high-energy wounds > 10 cm in length with extensive muscle devitalization. The wound is highly contaminated with extensive soft tissue damage.
       
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics & irrigation, & debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing & to prevent wound infections & osteomyelitis.
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels & nerves, which must be addressed as well.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Often, definitive treatment of the fracture is delayed until the wound is sufficiently cleaned & healthy soft tissue is available to cover the fracture.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • Increase in Gustillo grade is associated with increase in infection risk.
  • Compartment syndrome is rare in open fracture as it communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • External fixation device used is external to skin – external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out & distracted at the rate of 1 mm/day causing distraction at the callus & subsequently, lengthening can be done.
  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union & also for CTEV.

 

METHODS FOR INCREASING THE STABILITY OF EXTERNAL FIXATOR:

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leukoplakia

  • Leucoplakia is a condition characterized by white patches or plaques that develop on the mucous membranes of the mouth, throat, or other areas of the body.
  • The patches may be smooth, raised, or rough in texture and are usually non-painful, although they may become sore or irritated if they are rubbed or scraped.
  • Leucoplakia is most associated with tobacco use, including smoking and smokeless tobacco, and alcohol use, but may also be caused by other factors such as viral infections, chronic irritation, or poor oral hygiene.
  • While leucoplakia is usually harmless, some cases may progress to cancer or indicate the presence of an underlying cancer, particularly if the patches are red and raised or if they have irregular borders.
  • Treatment for leucoplakia may involve removal of the patches, discontinuing tobacco or alcohol use, and close monitoring for any signs of cancer development. Regular dental check-ups and good oral hygiene practices are also important in preventing and managing leucoplakia.

questions.text: A 2 years old child is brought to the emergency with history of fever and vomiting. On examination he has neck rigidity. The CSF examination shows polymorphs more than 2000/micro-liter, protein 100 mg/dl and glucose 10 mg/dl. The Gram stain shows the presence of Gram-negative coccobacilli. The culture shows growth of bacteria only on chocolate agar and not on blood agar. The causative agent is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Haemophilus influenzae

 

HAEMOPHILUS INFLUENZAE:

  • Small, pleomorphic, Gram-negative coccobacillus
  • Causes invasive or non-invasive infections
  • Invasive infections usually seen in children and caused by capsulated strain (m. c. type b strain). Meningitis is the most common invasive infection
  • Non-invasive infections seen mostly in adults and caused by non-capsulated strain

Laboratory diagnosis:

 

Specimen: CSF, Blood, Sputum

 

Microscopy:

 

Direct capsular antigen detection: by Latex agglutination

 

Culture:

  • Blood agar with Staph aureus streaked across the plate. Do not grow on blood agar alone
  • Chocolate agar
  • Nutrient agar enriched with factor V & factor X,
  • Levinthal’s medium
  • Fildes’ agar

Important points:

 

In meningitis, the CSF examination demonstrates:

  • Pleocytosis (4000-5000 WBCs/µL) with a predominance of neutrophils
  • Decreased CSF glucose levels
  • Increased CSF protein levels
  • Capsular antigen
  • Positive CSF Gram stain

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was watching Oppenheimer. Right at the scene of the atomic bomb blast, he developed severe crushing chest pain radiating to his arm. The patient was brought to the ER where his ECG was done which turned out to be normal. Echocardiography revealed the following finding. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women(post-menopausal)>men predominantly due to emotional>physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure. Beta2(Gs stimulation) at base and B2(Gi)activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes

 

Option C. Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV Myocardium

 

 

Option D. Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑JVP ↓Heart sounds ↓BP)

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes non-parametric tests?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is used for skewed distributions

 

Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand. They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.

 

Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Walli’s test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Option A is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

Other options:

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with painful & tender nodule on her shin. She reports that she had productive cough, low grade fever and weight loss for last six months. The biopsy of the lesions shows the following finding. What is the likely finding and the associated disease?

Ans. B. Langhans giant cell - Tuberculosis

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of TB and the biopsy finding shows a giant cell with nuclei arranged in a horse-shoe shape pattern, likely a Langhans giant cell.

 

Langhans giant cells are multinucleated cells with a horseshoe-shaped arrangement of nuclei that are typically present in granulomatous inflammation associated with tuberculosis. These giant cells are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells, which are activated macrophages that have taken up and processed the antigen. The presence of Langhans giant cells is a characteristic feature of granulomatous inflammation associated with tuberculosis.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extra-mucosal suture technique.

 

A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut: Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. It is often used for intestinal anastomoses, as it is absorbable and does not require removal. However, chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress.

 

B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

C. The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique: The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique (of Halstead) involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak.

 

D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique (of Lembert) involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis.

questions.solution:

Patient is in Rose position which is used for tonsillectomy. All 3 options are the advantages of this position. Both head and neck are extended in this position. A sand bag kept under the patient shoulder helps in achieving this position. It is contraindicated in patients with atlanto-axial instability.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the Medicine OPD with the complaints of recurrent abdominal pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, frequent diarrhea, loss of appetite and weight loss for last six months. Her lab investigations reveal ASCA antibody positivity. Which of the following features will not be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead pipe appearance

 

Lead-pipe appearance occurs in Ulcerative Colitis due to loss of haustrations.

 

All other features are seen in Crohn's disease

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Creeping mesenteric fat is seen
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Creeping mesenteric fat is seen

 

A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

B. Creeping mesenteric fat is seen during laparoscopy/laparotomy and is perhaps due to transmural inflammation of bowel

 

C. The proximal ileum is an uncommon site of involvement in Crohn's disease, it is the distal ileum. In addition to the terminal ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, rectum, and perianal region.

 

D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

choices.text: B-cell tyrosine kinase activity detection

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the Pediatrics OPD with eczematous rash over the skin. His past history reveals that he had recurrent skin infections and pneumonia in the past six months. Hemogram reveals low platelet count. Which of the following investigations should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. WASP gene mutation

 

The given clinical history (eczema, recurrent infections & low platelet count) is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. So, next step would be to evaluate for WASP gene mutation.

 

It is a X-linked recessive disorder characterized by low IgM and high IgE and IgA. It manifests as recurrent infections, eczematous rashes over the skin, increased risk of bleeding (low platelet count).

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Dislocation of wrist

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

Symptoms & Signs:

  • Fracture of the distal radius is commonly referred to as a Colles fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand).
  • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, & painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
  • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment & volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be seen.

Complications:

  • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, & compartment syndrome.
  • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, & fracture malunion or nonunion.

Treatment:

  • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable & are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint to reduce swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
  • Displaced fractures should undergo closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint.
  • Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fails to meet acceptable alignment criteria.
  • Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous pinning, external fixation, & open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).

Technique of closed manipulation:

  • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, by general or regional anesthesia.
  • The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he is ‘shaking hands’.
  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm from above the flexed elbow.
  • The surgeon then presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion & ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.
  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion & ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion & ulnar deviation.

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Staphylococcus aureus

 

Bacterial food poisoning due to preformed toxins (i.e. enterotoxins elaborated outside the host) usually have short incubation periods (<16 hrs).

 

Incubation period 1-6 hours:

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Bacillus cereus (emetic form)

Incubation period 8-16 hours:

  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Bacillus cereus (diarrheal form)

Incubation period >16 hours:

  • Vibrio cholerae
  • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)
  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli
  • Salmonella spp
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Shigella spp
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Important point:

  • The exotoxins causing diarrhea can be one of the three types – Enterotoxins, Cytotoxins or Neurotoxins

choices.text: Decreased postoperative pain
Deep cavity surgery is easier
Decreased heat loss
Short learning curve

questions.text: All are advantages of minimal access surgery except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Short learning curve

 

Learning curve is longer with minimal access surgery.

 

Advantages:

  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding, herniation and nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Early mobility
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved visualization

Disadvantages:

  • Long learning curve
  • Lack of tactile feedback
  • Difficulty in severe bleeding
  • Extraction of large specimens

questions.text: A man presents to a STD clinic with Urethritis and urethral discharge. Gram stain shows numerous pus cells but no microorganism. The culture is negative on the routine laboratory media. The most likely agent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia trachomatis

 

Bacterial causes for STD are:

  • Treponema pallidum
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • All other except Chlamydia trachomatis can be cultured on the routine laboratory media.
  • Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organism, and hence cannot be cultured on routine culture media.
  • They can be grown in various tissue cultures like McCoy & HeLa cells.
  • Chlamydiae form cytoplasmic inclusions. Intra-cytoplasmic inclusions can be detected either by Giemsa stains or by immunofluorescent staining with monoclonal antibodies.
  • The Gram staining is not useful as these are gram negative bacteria.

choices.text: Multiply by binary fission
Are sensitive to Beta lactam group of antibiotics
Can grow in cell free culture media
Require sterols for growth

questions.text: The following is true for Mycoplasma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Are sensitive to Beta lactam group of antibiotics

  • Mycoplasmas are the smallest free-living organisms that can be grown in a cell free media.
  • These organisms are unique among prokaryotes in that they lack a cell wall. They are bounded by a soft trilaminar unit membrane containing sterols.

Lack of cell wall provides it certain unique properties:

  • Pleomorphic with no fixed shape or size
  • Pass through bacterial filters
  • Resistant to beta lactams - penicillins & cephalosporins
  • Lack of reaction to Gram stain
  • Mycoplasmal organisms are usually associated with mucosal surfaces, residing extracellularly in the respiratory, gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts.
  • The treatment of choice is either macrolide or tetracycline such as doxycycline

Important points:

  • They have a specific requirement of sterols for growth and membrane synthesis.
  • Like other bacteria multiply by the binary fission.

Human infections are caused by:

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae– pneumonia
  • Mycoplasma hominis - genital tract infections
  • Mycoplasma genitalium- genital tract infections
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum - non-gonococcal urethritis

choices.text: Right testis is undescended and left testis is ectopic
Left testis is undescended and right testis is ectopic
Both testes are undescended
Both testes are ectopic

questions.text: A mother while bathing her newborn found the left sided scrotum to be empty. On examination by the pediatrician, left testis is in inguinal region and right testis is in perineum. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left testis is undescended and right testis is ectopic

 

The left testis in inguinal region is in normal path of descent and hence is undescended testis while right testis is at abnormal site in perineum and hence is ectopic.

choices.text: Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy is the most common subtype of GBS
Respiratory support should be provided to the patients
Steroids are the cornerstone of the management for this disease
CSF analysis will reveal increase proteins with normal cell count.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient, who has just recovered from a mild URTI, has presented to the OPD with the complaints of gradually progressive numbness and weakness in both his lower limbs, postural hypotension and urinary incontinence. On clinical examination, Knee jerk and ankle jerk were absent. Considering Guillain Barre Syndrome, which of the following statements is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Steroids are the cornerstone of the management for this disease

 

Steroids play no role in the management of the patients with Guillain-Barre syndrome.

 

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy is the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

It is an autoimmune condition that destroys Schwann cells via inflammation and demyelination of motor fibers, sensory fibers, peripheral nerves (including CN III-XII).

 

Likely facilitated by molecular mimicry and triggered by inoculations or stress. Despite association with infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, viruses [e.g., Zika]), no definitive causal link to any pathogen.

 

Results in symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis and depressed/absent DTRs beginning in lower extremities. Bilateral facial palsy and respiratory failure are common. It may also have autonomic dysfunction (e.g., cardiac irregularities, hypertension, hypotension) or sensory abnormalities. It has good prognosis with good recovery of functions.

 

CSF Analysis will reveal increased CSF protein with normal cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation).

 

Respiratory support is critical until recovery.

 

Disease-modifying treatment: plasma exchange or IV immunoglobulins.

 

No role for steroids in the management.

questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

The correct match is A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

choices.text: Membranous urethral injury
Acute urinary retention

questions.text: A 35-year-old man in an inebriated state fell in the bathroom and was taken to the casualty. He complained of intense pain in the suprapubic region. On examination, abdominal distention was present without suprapubic bulge. No blood was seen at urethral meatus. Heart rate and blood pressure was normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture

 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture commonly occurs when there is trauma/ direct blow to the urinary bladder when the bladder is full.  Urine drains into the abdominal cavity and thus suprapubic bulge is not seen. Features of chemical peritonitis are seen.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder injuries generally occur with pelvic fractures, while intraperitoneal bladder injuries occur with high-energy impact to an overdistended bladder. Extraperitoneal bladder injury is managed with an indwelling catheter, while intraperitoneal and complex bladder injuries are definitively repaired.

 

Membranous urethral injury presents with blood at the meatus and inability to pass urine.

questions.text: What value of BMI is considered as 'lethal' in men?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. <13

 

A body mass index (BMI) of 13 or less is considered lethal in men. However, females can survive even at a lower BMI up to 11.

 

The ability of females to withstand a greater degree of food deprivation may be due to the following reasons:

  • Greater body stores of fat that can be used as a source of energy for a much longer period (fat is more energy dense than protein)
  • Greater contribution of fat energy to total energy expenditure, resulting in a greater conservation of protein
  • Better mobilisation of adipose tissue from most sites in the body

choices.text: Enteroinvasive E. coli
Enterotoxigenic E. coli
Enteropathogenic E. coli

questions.text: A 20-year-old male had pain in abdomen and mild fever followed by gastroenteritis. The stool examination showed presence of pus cells and RBCs on microscopy. The etiological agent responsible is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enteroinvasive E. coli

 

Diarrheogenic E. coli: six different types

  • Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)
  • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)
  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)
  • Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC)
  • Diffusely adherent E. coli (DAEC)

Important point:

  • Out of the above only EIEC & EHEC may cause bloody diarrhea, others cause watery diarrhea.

questions.text: In Breslau's second life test, organ tested is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stomach and Intestine

  • Breslau's second life test: A live born child would respire and therefore, would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. Hence they float when put in water. This test is falsely positive in putrefaction (due to putrefied gases) or in cases of attempted artificial respiration.

Please note that Breslau's First life test detects presence of air in lungs

 

 

[Ref S.K. Singhal 4th/e p. 271]

choices.text: Inherited defect in PIG-A
Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient has red urine in the morning, abdominal pain and increasing fatigue over last few months. Blood investigations reveal coombs negative hemolytic anemia with pancytopenia. Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

 

Paroxysmal nocturnal Hemoglobinuria

 

Hematopoietic stem cell mutation, complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis, especially at night.

 

Acquired PIGA mutation

 

Impaired GPI anchor synthesis for decay-accelerating factor (DAF/CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL/CD59), which protect RBC membrane from complement.

 

Triad: Coombs negative hemolytic anemia (mainly intravascular), pancytopenia, venous thrombosis (e.g., Budd-Chiari syndrome). Pink/red urine in morning. Associated with aplastic anemia, acute leukemias.

 

Labs: Flow Cytometry - CD55/59 negative

 

Treatment: eculizumab (targets complement protein C5).

 

Option A. It is an acquired X-linked defect

 

Option B. Causes intravascular >>extravascular hemolysis

 

Option D. Causes hemolytic, normocytic anemia, and pancytopenia with venous thrombosis

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury
Incise and digitally explore wound prior to insertion

questions.text: A surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

An intercostal tube (ICD is placed along the upper border of the lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle.

 

Steps for insertion of an intercostal drain -

 

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • Above the level of the nipple.
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. This will ideally find the fifth space.

The technique includes the following.

  • Adequate local anaesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; these should only be the serratus anterior is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib.
  • Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.

After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph.

Varicella zoster virus

questions.text: A 40-year-old man underwent kidney transplantation for end stage renal disease. Two months after transplantation, he developed fever and feature suggestive of bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonia. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Cytomegalovirus

 

CMV is the predominant cause of infection in patient with renal transplant between 1-4 months after renal transplant.

 

Bilaterally interstitial or reticulonodular infiltrate in periphery of lower lobes

questions.text: A 30-years-old lady presents with low grade fever, painless oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus

 

Clinical history and dermatological features are suggestive of SLE

 

Clinical, serological criteria in the presence of positive ANA by IF is required to make a diagnosis of SLE.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with painful joints and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

questions.text: A patient who uses contact lenses is exhibiting the following clinical manifestations: persistent watering, redness, and a sensation of a foreign object in the eye over the last two months. What is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.
       

Other options:

 

Option A - In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B - Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D – Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

questions.text: The test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight is?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Ploucquet's Test

  • Ploucquet's test: Weight of lung is measured in relation to body weight. Before birth weight of lung is 1/70 of body weight and after respiration it becomes 1/35 of body weight due to increased blood flow in lung beds.
  • Static test or Fodere's test: The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 35 gm and after respiration is 70 gm
  • Wredin's test: Before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue which is replaced by air after respiration.
  • Raygat’s test (Hydrostatic test, Breslau’s 1st life test) : The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000).

 

 

[Ref S.K. Singhal 4ili/e p. 271]

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a mutation in the BCR (on chromosome 22) - ABL (on chromosome 9) fusion gene translocation. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML. The Philadelphia chromosome is detected with FISH (fluorescent in situ hybridisation).

choices.text: Serum for anti-rabies IgG antibody
Corneal impression smears for immunofluorescence stain
CSF sample for viral culture
Giemsa stain on smear prepared from salivary secretions

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl was admitted in the infectious disease hospital with a provisional diagnosis of rabies. The most suitable clinical sample that can confirm the antemortem diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Corneal impression smears for immunofluorescence stain

 

Laboratory diagnosis of human rabies:

  • Specimen: corneal smears, skin biopsy or saliva (antemortem) & brain (postmortem)

Direct Microscopy

  • Antemortem: demonstration of rabies virus antigen by direct immunofluorescence
  • Postmortem: demonstration of Negri bodies in brain

Isolation of virus

  • Animal inoculation: in mice brain
  • Tissue culture

Antibody detection in CSF by ELISA

 

RT-PCR: to detect rabies virus RNA

 

Important points:

  • Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions demonstrated in brain tissue.
  • Most abundant in hippocampus and cerebellum
  • May be absent in 20% cases
  • Stained by Seller’s stain

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the ratio of the disease incidence in the exposed group compared to the non-exposed group?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Relative risk

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR) (Cohort study).

 

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure (Cohort study).

 

Population attributable risk (PAR) is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be attributed to a particular exposure (Cohort study).

 

Odds ratio (OR) is the ratio of the odds of history of exposure in disease group and non-diseased group (Case control study)

a & c are correct
b & d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture.

  1. More common in males than females
  2. 1-year mortality rate is 20–30%
  3. More commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur
  4. 1-year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours
questions.solution:
Ans. C. b & d are correct

 

Fracture Neck of Femur

 

Garden’s Classification:

 

 

Pauwel’s Classification:

 

 

Clinical features:

  • Occasionally, a patient with an impacted fracture may arrive walking; the only complaint being little pain in the groin.
  • More often, the patient is an elderly, brought to the casualty with complaints of pain in the groin & inability to move his limb or bear weight on the limb following a ‘trivial’ injury like slipping on the floor, missing a step etc.
  • There is little pain or swelling. Often, the injury is trivial, & pain & swelling are almost absent. In such cases, the fracture diagnosis is missed for days or weeks.
  • Careful examinations reveal the following:
    • External rotation of the leg with the patella facing outwards
    • Slight shortening of the leg
    • Tenderness in the groin
    • Attempted hip movements are painful & associated with severe spasm
    • Active straight leg raising not possible
       

Treatment:

  • < 65 years, ≤ 3 weeks:
    • Closed reduction & internal fixation with multiple screw is the treatment of choice
    • Dynamic Hip Screw can be done
    • If closed reduction is not possible, open reduction & screw fixation is indicated
  • < 65 years, > 3-week fracture: Osteotomy/Bone grafting + fixation
  • ≥ 65 years:
    • No pre-existing arthritis – Hemiarthroplasty
    • Pre-existing arthritis (any age) – Total hip replacement – Complications are osteonecrosis > nonunion > arthritis
       

Intertrochanteric Fracture vs Neck of Femur Fracture:

 

  • Less lateral rotation deformity in fracture neck femur is due to attachment of capsule to the distal fracture fragment.

Intertrochanteric fracture femur

 

 

  • Treatment of choice:
    • Undisplaced fracture: Dynamic Hip Screw
    • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail)
  • Most common complication is malunion

Note: Latest literature claims better results with PFN

  • 1-year mortality rate is 20-30% - can be reduced by operating within 48 hours

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V regular insulin

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. He is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravenous fluids with I.V regular insulin

 

History is suggestive of DKA occurring in the presence of absolute insulin deficiency producing glucotoxicity and ketoacidosis with significant dehydration hence treatment initially aimed at correction of fluid deficit and bridging with insulin initiation.

 

Any form of insulin in IV form acts similarly. Only subcutaneously produces differences in half life.

 

Option A. IV insulin is required to correct glucotoxicity

 

Option B. IV fluids alone reduce CBG by 150-200 mg/dl and reduce acidosis however insulin infusion is required for correction of ketoacidosis completely

 

Option C. IV insulin alone will not correct fluid deficit in DKA.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure on a patient exhibiting symptoms indicative of peritonitis, a sigmoid diverticular rupture is observed, accompanied by fecal peritonitis. What would be the corresponding stage according to the Hinchey's classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stage 4

 

Hinchey's Classification is used to describe the severity of diverticular disease and its complications, particularly diverticulitis. It consists of the following stages:

 

Stage 0: Mild clinical diverticulitis treated with antibiotics alone.

 

Stage I: Diverticulitis with a pericolic or mesenteric abscess (localized pus collection).

 

Stage II: Diverticulitis with a walled off pelvic abscess (more extensive pus collection).

 

Stage III: Diverticulitis with generalized purulent peritonitis (infection has spread throughout the abdominal cavity, but no feces are present).

 

Stage IV: Diverticulitis with generalized fecal peritonitis (infection has spread throughout the abdominal cavity, and feces are present due to a perforation in a diverticulum).

 

So, in the case of the patient with a diverticular perforation and fecal peritonitis, this would be classified as Hinchey Stage IV.

questions.text: Ebstein Barr virus is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma nasopharynx

 

Viruses associated with human cancer

questions.text: How are cytotoxic and expired drugs disposed of in a systematic manner?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Incineration

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was admitted to the Medicine Ward with Tuberculosis. He developed high grade fever and had episodes of seizures. He appears confused and is not oriented to time place and person. His CSF analysis revealed the following findings. What should be the management of this patient?

The clinical scenario and the CSF findings (Cobweb coagulum and lymphocytosis) are pointing towards Tuberculous Meningitis. The treatment of TBM includes steroids administration in HIV negative TBM patients during the initial phases to reduce vasogenic edema and reduce the complications followed by administration of ATT therapy.

 

During the Induction phases, HRZE is given and during maintenance, only H and R are given to the patients.

Option D) This treatment is given for Cryptococcal meningitis in AIDS patients

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 0.5cm solid mass in her Gall Bladder on USG which is immobile and it is diagnosed as a gall bladder polyp. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reassure the patient and follow up

 

Gall bladder polyp upto 1cm → observation and follow up

 

More than 1cm → cholecystectomy

 

Cholecystectomy should be performed for all gallbladder polyps greater than 1 cm. Polyps less than 1cm can be Followed with serial ultrasonography to detect any change in size or character as the incidence of malignancy in Polyps less than 1cm is extremely low.

choices.text: Component bar graph
Multiple bar graphs

questions.text: Which statistical diagram is used in the given chart that represents the population change over the years from 1983 to 1989 in a specific location?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Component bar graph

 

The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.

 

A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data, typically qualitative discrete data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs in type.

 

In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Multiple Bar Graphs:

 

 

Histogram:

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram (continuous quantitative data), the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Line Diagram:

 

 

A line chart provides the clearest graphical representation of time-dependent variables. It is also the preferred mode of representing trends or variables over a period of time.

questions.text: MTP can be done up to 24 weeks for?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Rape Victim

  • MTP in Contraceptive failure and social indication is allowed only till 20 weeks
  • MTP in Rape is allowed only till 24 weeks
  • MTP in Congenital malformation can be done even after 24 weeks

MTP Act, India:

  • 1st Act passed in: 1971
  • Latest Amendment: 2021

Key features of MTPC act as per latest amendment:

 

1. MTP Till 20 Weeks:

  • Only 1 Doctor opinion required
  • MTP permitted for a broad range of conditions:
    • Risk to mother: The life is at risk or grave injury (physical / Mental) to health of mother
    • Risk to baby: Serious mental or physical congenital abnormalities;
    • Rape
    • Contraceptive failure:
       
  • Either by woman or man.
  • Allowed for both married and unmarried woman (earlier this clause was only for married woman)
    • Bad Socio-economic condition (Poor family and already has 2–3 children)
       

2. MTP between 20-24 weeks:

  • 2 doctors' opinion required;
  • Allowed in few special categories:
    • Rape
    • Minors
    • Disabled women (Physical / mentally ill)
    • Significant fetal anomalies
    • Change of marital status during pregnancy (widowhood and divorce)
    • Women with pregnancy in humanitarian settings or disaster or emergency
       

3. MTP > 24 weeks:

  • A state-level Medical Board required ( consisting of Gynecologist, Pediatrician, Radiologist,  other members as appointed by Govt.)
  • Allowed only in significant fetal anomalies.

Consent required for MTP

  1.  Pregnancy of a woman > 18 years of age: only her own consent
  2. < 18 years or mentally ill: Consent of the guardian

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the OPD with abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. An image of his lower limbs is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria due to nephritic syndrome. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

Option A - Immune thrombocytopenic purpura typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B - Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C - Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

questions.text: Imaging modality of choice for fistula in ano is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. MRI

  • Gold standard investigation for fistula-in-ano is MRI.
  • A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, lined with granulation tissue.
  • Etiology - Perianal, tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.
  • Clinical features - Perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which might be blood-stained. On examination, one or more external openings may be visible.
  • Goodsall’s rule – It is used to predict the course of fistula tract and the internal opening.
  • Fistulae are classified according to Park’s classification.

questions.text: A patient, resident of Himachal Pradesh, presented with a series of ulcers in a row, on his right leg. The biopsy from the affected area was taken and cultured on Sabouraud’s Dextrose agar. What would be the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sporothrix schenckii

 

SPOROTRICHOSIS:

  • Sporotrichosis is endemic in the sub-Himalayan region and caused by Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation. When introduced into the skin, typically by abrasion or prick, it causes a local pustule or ulcer with nodules along the draining lymphatics.

Important points:

  • Sporotrichosis occurs most often in gardeners.
  • Characteristic ‘Asteroid bodies’ are seen on staining with methenamine silver
  • The drug of choice for skin lesion is itraconazole.

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker was brought to the OPD with the long-standing history of cough, weight loss for last one year for which he was admitted in the Medicine Ward. His Urine output was noted to be 200 mL/day with raised urine osmolality. His X-ray revealed a centrally localised mass in the left lung. Biopsy of the mass reveals the following finding. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Small cell lung cancer

 

The clinical history (male smoker with cough weight loss) and X-ray finding of a central mass in the lung is suggestive of Lung carcinoma. The biopsy finding shows increased basophilic staining (Azzopardi effect) which is seen in small cell carcinoma of the lung. Low urine output with high urine osmolality is suggestive of associated SIADH syndrome which is a paraneoplastic manifestation seen with Small Cell Carcinoma of Lung.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, a screening test for Diabetes Mellitus (DM) identified 90 people as positive. A gold standard test for DM was then conducted, and it identified 100 positive cases. Calculate the sensitivity of the screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 90/100

 

In case question, the following data are provided:

 

Total population = 1000

 

Total diseased people = 100 (identified by gold standard test)

 

Total number of diabetics identified initially = 90, thus total positive identified by screening test =90

 

 

Therefore:

 

Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) =90/ (90+10) = 90/100 = 90%

questions.text: Kala-Azar is endemic in all these areas except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Assam

 

Kala-Azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania donovani parasite. It is transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies.

 

Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. It is endemic in the following states in 54 districts:

  • Uttar Pradesh
  • West Bengal
  • Bihar
  • Jharkhand

Current situation: India contributes about 11.5% of total cases of Kala-azar reported globally. Over 90% of kala-azar cases in India are reported from Bihar and Jharkhand, while Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal have achieved their elimination targets at the block level.

questions.solution:

Antidepressants act as Na-channel blockers and patients presenting with hypotension and wide QRS suggest TCA overdose. Antidote is IV HCO3

A. “S” wave in lead I

 

B. Terminal R wave in lead aVR

 

QRS >100ms is predictive if impending arrhythmia and seizure

 

Effective agents for TCA toxicity include 1. NaHCO3 2. Lignocaine 3. Lipid emulsion

questions.text: Waxing and waning type of jaundice is seen in which associated etiology of obstructive jaundice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Peri ampullary carcinoma

 

Peri ampullary carcinoma includes:

  • Carcinoma of head of pancreas
  • Distal CBD cancer
  • Ampullary carcinoma

These present with waxing and waning type of jaundice due to the fact that jaundice may intermittently wax and wane because of central necrosis and sloughing or pressure opening of a minimally obstructed duct.

 

Obstructive jaundice due to CBD stones is usually intermittent in nature with biliary colic.

questions.text: A young male with fever, cough, night sweats and bilateral facial palsy. Investigations reveal enlargement of bilateral hilar lymph nodes. Which of the following is the correct pair of the likely diagnosis and the pathological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sarcoidosis – Schaumann bodies

 

History of B/L VII palsy with B/L hilar lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms suggest sarcoidosis. On Histopathological examination, Schaumann bodies are seen.

 

 

Option B. TB usually does not produce B/L hilar node and VII palsy

questions.text: The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary attack rate

 

The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is called secondary attack rate.

 

It is calculated by the following formula:

 

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period × 100)/ (Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible).

 

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

choices.text: De Quervain's thyroiditis

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painful, tender, and swollen thyroid gland. She reports a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and exquisitely tender to touch. Laboratory tests show elevated thyroid hormone levels and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. De Quervain's thyroiditis

 

Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain's thyroiditis, is a self-limiting inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland. It often follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection and typically presents with painful, tender, and swollen thyroid gland. The pain is exacerbated by palpation (tender to touch). Laboratory findings may reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels due to the release of preformed thyroid hormones from the inflamed gland. The ESR is also elevated, indicating the presence of inflammation.

 

Option a) Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism, but it is not associated with a painful or tender thyroid gland. Instead, it may present with diffuse thyroid enlargement, goiter, and eye changes (ophthalmopathy).

 

Option b) Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hypothyroidism, but it is not associated with a painful or tender thyroid gland. The thyroid gland in Hashimoto's thyroiditis is typically diffusely enlarged and firm.

 

Option d) Thyroid carcinoma is a type of thyroid cancer. While thyroid cancer may present with a thyroid nodule or mass, it is not associated with the characteristic painful and tender thyroid gland seen in subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following class specific antigenic determinants of an immunoglobulin is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. H-chain

 

Antibodies (Immunoglobulins) contain four polypeptide chains

  • Two identical light (L) chains & two identicalheavy (H) chains.

L (Light) chains:

  • Similar in all Ig classes.
  • L chains are of two types – kappa&lambda.
  • An Ig can have either of kappa or lambda chains but never both.

H (Heavy) chains:

  • Structurally and antigenically distinct for each Ig class.
  • Alpha (IgA), Gamma (IgG), Delta (IgD), Epsilon (IgE) & Mu (IgM).
  • It is the type of H-chain which determines the class of Immunoglobulin

Important points:

  • J chain:Joins the immunoglobulin molecules to form polymeric Ig like IgA & IgM.(J for joining)
  • Variable region:a region of variable amino-acid sequence at amino-terminus of both H-chain & L-chain which participates in antigen recognition

questions.text: Identify changes over body?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Filigree burns

 

Filigree burns:

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 - 48 hours if the person survives.

 

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 181.

Ans. A. Consolidation with air bronchogram

 

History is suggestive of pneumonia. CT shows consolidation with air bronchograms. Patent bronchus seen in the areas of consolidation is termed “air bronchograms”.

 

Option B. Mediastinal mass is seen only in either of the compartments of anterior, middle or posterior mediastinum.

choices.text: The presence of ingested erythrocytes is seen only in Entamoeba histolytica
Young adult male of low socioeconomic status is most commonly affected by invasive amoebiasis
Low iron content in the diet predisposes to invasive amoebiasis
The pathogenic and non-pathogenic strains of E. histolytica can be differentiated by the electrophoretic study of zymodemes

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low iron content in the diet predisposes to invasive amoebiasis

 

Factors affecting virulence of Entamoeba histolytica:

 

Amoebic factors: Cystine proteinase, Lectin, Ionophore proteins

 

Host factors: Age (30-60 years), males>females, stress, malnutrition, alcoholism, corticosteroid therapy, immunodeficiency

 

Colonic factors: alteration in quality of colonic mucus (glycoproteins in mucus prevent attachment of trophozoite to epithelial cells), colonic bacterial flora

 

Zymodemes:

  • Are a group of parasites with the same isoenzymes
  • Based on electrophoretic mobility of six isoenzymes, E. histolytica is classified into 22 zymodemes
  • Of these 9 are invasive and rest are non-invasive commensals
  • They have been proposed to represent two different species – Pathogenic E. histolytica& non-pathogenic E. dispar
  • Trophozoites of E. dispar contain bacteria but no RBCs, while E. histolytica contain RBCs as well.
  • Zymodemes show a geographical distribution
  • Even in endemic areas nonpathogenic zymodemes are far more common (90%) than pathogenic zymodemes (10%)

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents with symptoms of sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and mild fever. Upon examination, the clinical picture suggests a specific condition as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the vaccine that could have potentially prevented this condition?

The image shows a dirty white pseudomembrane classic of Diphtheria.

 

A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees is taken as a contraindication. Reactions such as shock, collapse, persistent screaming episodes, convulsions, anaphylaxis are other contraindications for subsequent vaccination.

  • The cellular component of pertussis is not recommended after 7 years.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient has presented to the OPD after sustaining a minor injury to his hand while playing basketball. He reports that the bleeding didn’t stop even after applying pressure. On examination, multiple petechial and ecchymotic spots are observed. Hemogram reveals low platelet count. Peripheral smear findings are shown below. The most probable diagnosis of this patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bernard Soulier syndrome

 

The given clinical history is pointing towards a platelet disorder. Thrombocytopenia with the smear findings showing abnormally large platelets (as compared with RBCs), is suggestive of Bernard Soulier syndrome. It is a platelet adhesion defect, due to defect in Gp 1b/IX.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an inherited bleeding disorder characterized by the absence or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GP IIb/IIIa) receptors on platelets. These receptors play a crucial role in platelet aggregation and clot formation. As a result, individuals with Glanzmann thrombasthenia have difficulty forming stable blood clots, leading to prolonged bleeding episodes after injuries or surgeries.

 

Option C) ITP is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of platelets by the body's immune system. It leads to a decreased platelet count (thrombocytopenia), which can result in easy bruising, petechiae, and other bleeding manifestations. ITP can be acute or chronic and is often diagnosed through blood tests and exclusion of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D) DIC is a serious, life-threatening condition that occurs as a secondary response to various underlying diseases or conditions, such as severe infections, trauma, or certain types of cancers. In DIC, the body's normal clotting mechanism becomes overactivated, leading to widespread clot formation within small blood vessels. As a consequence, the clotting factors become depleted, leading to an increased risk of bleeding. DIC can manifest with both bleeding and clotting symptoms.

choices.text: It is the leading cause of death in patients with blood transfusion

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was undergoing plasma transfusion when he developed a sudden onset dyspnoea, bilateral crackles over the lower lung fields, reduced oxygen saturation. His blood pressure and jugular venous pressure are normal. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of this patient is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It occurs due to antibodies against Rh antigens

 

Patient undergoing blood transfusion with the features of dyspnea, falling saturation and bilateral crackles over lower lung fields is pointing towards pulmonary edema. Normal blood pressure and JVP rules out cardiogenic cause. So, the diagnosis is Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema.

 

Acute Lung Injury after Fresh Frozen Plasma transfusion is the leading cause of death in such patients. It occurs due to antibodies against the HLA antigens.

 

It is characterised by alveolar injury with deposition of thick gelatinous material in the alveoli, thereby reducing its compliance and also the gaseous exchange.

questions.solution:
