Serological tests to detect antigen or antibody against protozoal or helminthic infections can be used for their diagnosis.

 

Antigens detected in parasitic diseases:

questions.text: In the given natural history of disease flowchart, the segment from point A to point C is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead time

 

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C).

 

Time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis, that is between point A and point B is the screening time.

 

Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred.

 

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis. That is conditions with a long lead time.

 

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

questions.text: In a normal distribution curve, what is the proportion or percentage of data that falls within one standard deviation from the mean?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 68%

 

In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the values fall within one standard deviation of the mean. Therefore, the correct answer is A. 68%.

 

This means that if the data is normally distributed, about 68% of the observations will fall within one standard deviation of the mean, about 95% of the observations will fall within two standard deviations of the mean, and about 99.7% of the observations will fall within three standard deviations of the mean.

 

So, option B. 34% is incorrect as it refers to the percentage of values within half a standard deviation of the mean.

 

Option C. 99% and Option D. 95% are incorrect as they refer to the percentages of values within two and three standard deviations of the mean, respectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with features of acute meningoencephalitis in the casualty. His CSF on wet mount microscopy revealed motile unicellular microorganisms. The most likely organism is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Naegleria fowleri

 

PROTOZOAL CAUSES OF MENINGOENCEPHALITIS:

 

Acute meningoencephalitis:

  • Naegleria fowleri (primary amebic meningoencephalitis)
  • Trypanosoma cruzi

Subacute/Chronic meningoencephalitis:

  • Acanthamoeba (subacute/chronic granulomatous amebic meningoencephalitis)
  • Balamuthia mandrillaris (subacute/chronic granulomatous amebic meningoencephalitis)
  • Baylisascaris procyonis
  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis
  • Trypanosoma brucei gambiense
  • Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense

Important points:

  • Diagnosis of N. fowleri infection is by detection of motile trophozoites in wet mounts of fresh CSF.
  • N. fowleri is a free living fresh-water amoeba causing acute meningoencephalitis in immunocompetent persons.

questions.text: As per Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, a 6-month-old child is diagnosed with pneumonia if the child exhibits fast breathing with a respiratory rate higher than?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50

 

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate (RR): distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not.
  • Children are classified as pneumonia if:
    • >60/min RR for infants <2 months of age.
    • > 50/min RR for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40/min RR for children 12 months to 5 years of age.
  • Lower chest wall indrawing indicates severe pneumonia
  • Stridor indicates those with severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH, 7.2; pC02, 81mm Hg; and HCO3, 40 meq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

pH 7.2(acidosis) → pCO2(↑) vs HCO3(↓) - Here pCO2 ↑ = Respiratory acidosis.

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis results from hyperventilation.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis occurs due to loss of HCO3 or Excess H+ absorption

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis results from gain of HCO3 or loss of H+ from GI or non-GI source

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

History is suggestive of Takayasu arteritis which is a common large vessel vasculitis affecting the Asian population characterized by classical “pulseless disease” due to subclavian artery involvement commonly.

 

Extent of involvement should be carefully evaluated for mainly abdominal, renal involvement

 

Fundus appearance is aka “Boxcar ring appearance”

 

Treatment with low dose steroids, methotrexate is optimized before considering stenting and other endovascular procedures

 

Option A. PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis usually not involving subclavian artery

 

Option B. Buerger's disease is a small vessel vasculitis seen in male smokers

 

Option D. MPA is a medium to small vessel non-granulomatous vasculitis affecting elderly patients.

questions.text: In a study comparing two groups, where one group serves as the control, which test is the preferred method to measure the difference in means between the two groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Unpaired t test

 

The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is unpaired T test.

 

The unpaired t-test is a statistical test used to compare the means of two independent groups. It assumes that the data are normally distributed and that the variances of the two groups are equal.

 

In contrast, the paired t-test is used to compare the means of one group with paired data, such as before and after measurements on the same individuals. The chi-square test is used to compare the proportions of categorical data between two or more groups. The z-test is used, instead of t-test, when the sample size is large and the population variance is known.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which subject or issue is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adulteration of food

 

Adulteration of food is included under the concurrent list.

 

The legislative section of the seventh schedule is divided into three lists:

  • Union list - a list of 100 items on which the parliament has exclusive power to legislate
  • State list - a list of 61 items on which the state government has exclusive power to legislate
  • Concurrent list - a list of 52 items on which both central and state governments have the power to legislate
